This species is mottled brown/black and is found in freshwater streams and lakes in the Orinoco River basin in Venezuela. P. multiradiatus prefers warm water temperatures

name: Golden dwarf sucker, golden oto
description: Otocinclus macrospilus is a small catfish species native to South America, specifically found in the Amazon River basin. It reaches a size of 3.5 cm (1.4 inches) and is popular in the aquarium trade, often known as the common otocinclus or dwarf otocinclus. However, confusion can arise with other similar species from the Otocinclus and Macrotocinclus genera.

name: Zebra dwarf sucker, zebra oto
description: The zebra oto (Otocinclus cocama) is a small fish originating from Peru, specifically found in the Ucayali River and possibly the Marañón River. It has distinctive vertical stripe-like blotches and a complete lateral line, with a "W" mark on its caudal fin. This species has the highest number of teeth among Otocinclus species and reaches about 4.4 cm in length. The zebra oto is endangered due to its

name: Clown Pleco ( L104, L162, and LDA22)[18]
remarks: primary diet consists of wood, in aquaria this is provided in the source of drift wood. Will appreciate blanched vegetables, and/ or algae (wafer or live)[18]
description: Panaqolus maccus, also known as the clown panaque or clown pleco, is a dwarf loricariid fish native to Venezuela and Colombia. It typically grows up to 8.8 centimeters in length and has a striped pattern that may vary with age. This species thrives in aquariums with driftwood and a varied diet of fresh vegetables, spirulina, and frozen foods. They are peaceful and hardy fish suitable for community tanks, requiring good

name: Bolt catfish
description: Aguarunichthys torosus, also known as the Bolt Catfish or Yellow-band Catfish, is a benthopelagic catfish native to the Cenepa River basin in the Amazon River drainage of Peru. It is exclusively found in the Río Marañón in the upper Amazon basin of Peru and can grow up to 346 mm in length.

name: Gold Zebra catfish
description: Brachyplatystoma juruense, also known as the zebra catfish, is a species of catfish native to the Amazon and Orinoco River basin in northwestern Brazil, Peru, and Venezuela. It can grow up to 60.0 cm in length and is found in larger, deeper river channels with a sandy substrate and driftwood. The adult zebra catfish has broad dark vertical, oblique, or branching bands, a pale yellowish ventrum, and

name: Zebra shovelnose
description: The zebra shovelnose, or tigerstriped catfish (Brachyplatystoma tigrinum), is a large piscivorous catfish native to the Amazon basin in Brazil, Colombia, and Peru. It is found in fast-flowing sections of whitewater rivers and clearwater rivers in the upper Amazon basin. Adults can reach up to 85 cm in length and 5.2 kg in weight. They have an elongate, compressed head, long filaments

name: Vulture Catfish, zamurito
description: Calophysus macropterus, also known as Piracatinga or Vulture Catfish, is a small catfish species native to the Amazon and Orinoco basins. It can reach up to 40 centimeters in length and is known for its adaptability and hardiness. However, it has a reputation for attacking other fish in aquariums, so tankmates should be chosen carefully. Despite its potential for aggression, some owners have reported no issues when keeping this species.

Leiarius is a genus of long-whiskered catfish native to South America, popular in the aquarium hobby. There are four recognized species in this genus, with L. marmoratus reaching over 100 cm and 12 kg, and L. pictus growing up to 60 cm. L. pictus has a brown body with darker spots and pale ventral coloring. Both species have long maxillary barbels that shorten as they grow, with sail-like dorsal fins. L

Leiarius is a genus of long-whiskered catfish native to South America, popular in the aquarium hobby. The genus includes four recognized species, with L. marmoratus reaching over 100 cm and 12 kg, while L. pictus grows to 60 cm. These species have distinct features such as long maxillary barbels and sail-like dorsal fins. L. marmoratus is found in multiple river basins, while L. pictus is limited to the Amazon

name: Redtail catfish
tank_size: Needs at least a 2,600 US gallons (9,800 L) tank when mature, even though this does not provide them with the space to show their natural behaviour.[22]
description: The redtail catfish, Phractocephalus hemioliopterus, is a large pimelodid catfish native to South America, specifically the Amazon, Orinoco, and Essequibo river basins. It can reach up to 1.8 meters in length and 80 kilograms in weight, although most individuals are smaller. They have a distinctive appearance with a brownish back, yellow sides, and orange-red dorsal and caudal fins. Redtail

name: Spotted pimelodus, pictus, pictus catfish
description: Pimelodus pictus, also known as the pictus cat or pictus catfish, is a small catfish native to the Amazon and Orinoco river basins. They are popular in freshwater aquariums, known for their silver color with black spots and stripes, long barbels, and sharp spines on their fins. They are active swimmers and nocturnal bottom feeders, preferring soft water and a varied diet including bloodworms, beef heart, and vegetables. They

name: Ornate Pimelodus
remarks: Similar to catfish but not in the same genus
description: Pimelodus ornatus, also known as the ornate pimelodus, is a fish in the Pimelodidae family. They typically grow to a size of 24-28 cm. These fish are found in countries such as Colombia, Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname, Ecuador, Peru, Brazil, Paraguay, and Argentina.

name: Sturgeon catfish
description: Platystoma sturio, also known as the sturgeon catfish, is the only species in the genus Platystomatichthys of the catfish family Pimelodidae. It is found in the Amazon Basin and can grow up to about 40.0 centimeters (15.7 inches) in length. Classified under the "Calophysus-Pimelodus clade," it is part of the "Pimelodus-group" of Pimel

name: Barred sorubim
description: Pseudoplatystoma fasciatum, also known as barred sorubim or barred catfish, is a nocturnal predator native to Suriname, Corantijn, and Essequibo. Females of this species grow larger than males, reaching up to 90 cm in length. They become sexually mature at 56 cm for females and 45 cm for males. The species is of interest in aquaculture for food production and conservation purposes. Reproduction can be induced with two

name: Tiger sorubim
description: The Tiger Sorubim, also known as Pseudoplatystoma tigrinum, is a long-whiskered catfish native to the Amazon Basin in South America. It can grow up to 130 cm (51 in) in total length, although most individuals are smaller.

name: Firewood catfish, (planiceps) shovelnose catfish
description: The firewood catfish, also known as Sorubimichthys planiceps, is a South American pimelodid catfish found in the Orinoco and Amazon Basins. It is named after its little eating value, leading locals to dry and use it as firewood. These fish can grow up to 150 cm (5 ft) in length and are mainly nocturnal predators, feeding on other fish. As they mature, their appearance changes, with adults having an ash

name: Cuckoo squeaker
description: Synodontis multipunctatus, also known as the cuckoo catfish, is a small catfish species from Lake Tanganyika in Africa. It grows up to 27.5 centimeters in length and is a brood parasite, using mouthbrooding cichlids as caretakers for their young. They are a minor component of local fisheries and are known for their breeding behavior. In aquariums, they grow to about 15 centimeters and can be bred successfully with suitable host

name: Decorated squeaker
description: Synodontis decorus, also known as clown catfish or clown synodontis, is a unique species of upside-down catfish native to Cameroon, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and the Republic of the Congo in the Congo basin. It is characterized by a long dorsal fin that extends back to its caudal fin, making it a popular choice among catfish enthusiasts. This fish has a compressed head and body, with three pairs of barbells. Its body is mostly white with

name: Even-Spotted squeaker
description: Synodontis petricola, also known as the cuckoo catfish or pygmy leopard catfish, is a species of upside-down catfish found in Lake Tanganyika in Burundi, Zambia, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and Tanzania. It has a distinctive appearance with a bony head, triangular humeral process, and unique barbel characteristics. This fish species has specific fin structures, skin folds, and tooth arrangements that aid in its identification. It has a maximum length

name: Featherfin squeaker
description: The featherfin squeaker (Synodontis eupterus) is a species of Synodontis catfish known for its ability to make noises for communication. They are found in the basins of the White Nile, Volta, and Niger Rivers and the Chad Basin. These fish have a distinctive feather-like fin that is popular among hobbyists. Wild featherfin squeakers can grow up to 30.0 centimetres (11.8 in) in length.

name: Lake Malawi syno
description: The Malawi squeaker (Synodontis njassae) is an upside-down catfish found in Lake Malawi, growing up to 19.2 cm in length. It is a minor catch in local fisheries and is popular in the aquarium trade.

name: Polka dot syno
description: Synodontis angelicus, also known as polkadot squeaker or black clown catfish, is a species of upside-down catfish native to the Congo Basin in Africa. It was first described in 1891 and is known for its distinctive coloring, with adults being grey to dark violet with reddish-yellow blotches. Juveniles have white round blotches on a red-violet background. This species can grow up to 25 centimeters in length and is popular in the aquarium trade

name: Common syno, false upside-down catfish
description: Synodontis nigrita, also known as the false upside-down catfish, is a species of upside-down catfish found widely in northern Africa. It was first described in 1840 and has distinct features such as a bony head capsule, three pairs of barbels, and hardened spines on its fins. This fish species has a brown to blackish body color with round black spots and can grow up to 33.5 centimeters in length. It is found in various river

name: Upside-down catfish
remarks: S. nigriventris prefers bottom feeding on Tubifex (or similar worms), but its main diet consists of algae.[23] The blotched upside-down catfish is well suited to aquariums because of its small size (typically 9 or 10 cm or less) and peaceful demeanor.[citation needed]
description: Synodontis nigriventris, also known as the blotched upside-down catfish, is a small fish species native to the Congo Basin. They reach a maximum size of 9.6 cm and have large eyes, a large dorsal fin, and three pairs of barbels. These fish are adapted to swim upside-down, with darker bellies for camouflage. They are mostly nocturnal and feed on insects, crustaceans, and plant matter. Adults swim and rest upside down,

name: Three-striped African catfish
description: Pareutropius buffei, also known as the three-striped African catfish, is a small fish species belonging to the Schilbeidae family. It grows up to 8 centimeters in length and has a silvery body with three lateral stripes and black spots on its caudal fin. Native to Nigeria, Niger, Mali, Benin, and Guinea, this fish species is found in rivers and freshwater lagoons. It is sometimes kept as an aquarium pet.

name: Giraffe catfish
description: The giraffe catfish, Auchenoglanis occidentalis, is an African catfish found in lakes and rivers across Africa. It feeds on plants, insects, and has an omnivorous diet. It can grow up to two to three feet in size and has a giraffe-like pattern that fades with age. The male guards the scattered eggs in a nest. This fish is occasionally imported for the aquarium trade but is not suitable for smaller tanks due to its large size and fast growth

name: Electric catfish
description: Malapterurus electricus is a large, brownish or grayish fish with six mouth barbels and a single dorsal fin. It can grow up to 1.2 meters in length and 23 kilograms in weight. This fish is known for its ability to generate and control up to 450 volts of electricity, which it uses for defense and hunting. It is found in African waters such as the Nile, Lake Turkana, and Lake Chad basins. Malapterurus electricus feeds

name: Black lancer catfish
description: The black lancer (Bagrichthys macracanthus) is a bagrid catfish species found in Vietnam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, and Thailand, reaching up to 25.0 cm in length. It is the only species in its genus traded for aquariums. They are initially imported young and in poor condition, requiring acclimation at around 29°C. Despite being nocturnal, they can be trained to eat in light and even from the owner's hand

name: Harlequin lancer catfish
description: Bagroides melapterus, also known as the harlequin lancer catfish, is a slender catfish species belonging to the Bagridae family. It can grow up to 34.0 cm in length and has a silver coloration with distinctive black spots and markings. This species is native to Asia, particularly found in countries such as Thailand, Malaysia, Brunei, and Indonesia.

name: Crystal-eyed catfish
description: Hemibagrus wyckii, also known as the crystal-eyed catfish or black devil catfish, is a species of catfish found in Asia from Thailand to Indonesia. They have a black body with white markings on the fins and striking sky blue eyes, reaching up to 71 centimeters in length. These fish are aggressive predators, feeding on insects, prawns, and other fish. They are known to be unafraid of humans and can be aggressive towards other fish in the

name: Asian redtail catfish
description: The Hemibagrus wyckioides, also known as the Asian redtail catfish, is a large catfish species native to the Mekong basin and found in rivers in Thailand. It can reach up to 130 centimeters in length and weigh up to 80 kilograms. These catfish have a distinct red tail fin and are commonly found in rocky river areas. They do not migrate but reproduce locally during high water seasons. Their diet consists of insects, prawns, fish,

name: Shadow catfish
description: Hyalobagrus flavus is a bagrid catfish species found in Indonesia, specifically in the Batang Hari drainage in Sumatra and the Mentaya River basin in southern Borneo. They prefer brown water habitats near blackwater peat swamps and are known to form large shoals, occasionally mingling with other shoaling catfish species.

Mystus bimaculatus is a catfish species with a red-brown body and two dark markings on its shoulder and caudal peduncle. It is found in Indonesia, particularly on Java and the Lesser Sunda Islands. This species is classified as near threatened.

name: Glass catfish
description: Kryptopterus vitreolus, also known as the glass catfish or ghost catfish, is a small transparent freshwater catfish species native to Thailand. It was previously confused with other species but was officially described in 2013. They have a unique transparent body due to their scaleless nature and lack of body pigment. They are commonly found in the aquarium trade, although concerns exist about the sustainability of wild-caught specimens. They are known to react to electromagnetic fields due to a specific

name: Striped wallago catfish
description: Wallagonia leerii, also known as the Great Tapah, is a large catfish species native to Southeast Asia, specifically found in river drainages from Thailand to Indonesia. It can reach lengths of up to 2 meters and weigh up to 150 kg. The species has been traditionally used as food but is now facing population decline due to overfishing and habitat destruction, particularly from damming. The Great Tapah is a piscivore, feeding primarily on small fish. It faces

name: Chocolate frogmouth catfish
description: Chaca bankanensis is a small angler catfish species native to the Sundaland region, specifically found in Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. It inhabits peat swamps and streams and can grow up to 20.0 cm (7.9 in) in length. This species is popular in the aquarium trade.

name: Asian banjo catfish
description: Acrochordonichthys rugosus is a catfish species belonging to the Akysidae family. It is found in clear, fast-flowing forested streams in Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. For more information on its relationship with other members of its genus, refer to the Acrochordonichthys page on Wikipedia.

name: Walking catfish
remarks: The albino form is common in the aquarium trade. This fish can survive out of the water and "walk" as long as kept wet, for a very long time.[25]
description: The walking catfish (Clarias batrachus) is a freshwater airbreathing catfish native to Southeast Asia known for its ability to "walk" across dry land using its pectoral fins. It can survive out of water for up to 18 hours and reaches almost 0.5 m in length. This species thrives in stagnant waters and feeds on smaller fish, molluscs, invertebrates, detritus, and aquatic weeds. Considerable taxonomic confusion exists

name: Stinging catfish
description: Heteropneustes fossilis, also known as Asian stinging catfish or fossil cat, is an airsac catfish found in various countries in Asia. It inhabits ponds, ditches, swamps, and muddy rivers, and can tolerate slightly brackish water. This omnivorous species breeds during the monsoon season and is valued for its alleged medicinal properties. It is known for its ability to deliver a painful sting to humans through a gland on its pectoral fin

name: Sun catfish
description: Horabagrus brachysoma, also known as the sun catfish, is a species of catfish native to rivers in the Western Ghats of India. It has a large head, wide mouth, and distinctive yellowish body with a black shoulder spot. This fish can grow up to 45 centimeters in length and is found in smooth flowing areas with abundant vegetation in rivers and backwaters. It has a flexible diet, feeding on crustaceans, molluscs, fish,

name: Iridescent shark
description: The iridescent shark, also known as the swai or Siamese shark catfish, is a freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia. Despite its name, it is not a shark but a species of shark catfish. It is popular for food and fishkeeping due to its striking appearance and iridescence. They can grow up to 130 cm in length and weigh up to 44 kg. Iridescent sharks prefer tropical climates and large bodies of water with specific pH, water

name: Chao Phraya giant shark, giant pangasius
description: The Giant Pangasius, also known as the Paroon Shark or Chao Phraya Giant Catfish, is a critically endangered freshwater fish found in the Chao Phraya and Mekong basins in Indochina. It can reach up to 300 centimeters in length and weigh up to 300 kilograms. This species is a top predator in its ecosystem, preying on shrimp, crabs, and fish. Due to overfishing, damming of rivers, and

name: Colombian shark catfish
description: The Tete sea catfish, also known as Ariopsis seemanni or Colombian shark catfish, is a species of sea catfish native to Central and South America. It is occasionally found in the pet trade under various names such as Colombian shark, silver tipped shark, and black fin shark. However, they are not suitable for most aquariums as they require acclimation from freshwater to saltwater as they grow. They need a large tank due to their size and active swimming behavior.

name: Banjo catfish
description: Bunocephalus coracoideus, also known as the guitarrito, is a banjo catfish species native to the Amazon River basin and found in Bolivia, Brazil, Peru, and Uruguay. It inhabits ponds and creeks with plant debris, feeding on organic matter and small fish. Popular in the aquarium trade, both male and female guitarritos grow up to 12 centimeters in length. They are peaceful but can prey on small fish like fry. Nocturnal in nature,

name: Striped raphael catfish
description: The Striped Raphael catfish, also known as Platydoras armatulus, is a peaceful and nocturnal species native to South America. It is popular in aquariums for its friendly nature and curious behavior. They feed on mollusks, crustaceans, and organic debris, and can grow up to 24 cm in length. They have protective spines along their body and are known to make grunting noises out of water. Although sociable, they may feed on smaller fish,

name: Spotted raphael catfish
description: Agamyxis pectinifrons, also known as the spotted talking catfish, is a thorny catfish species found in the Amazon basin. It reaches a length of 15 centimeters and is popular in the aquarium trade. It requires a dark hiding spot during the day and should be handled carefully due to its spines. This species is known for making audible clicking sounds.

name: Bottlenose catfish
description: Ageneiosus inermis, also known as the mandubé, is a driftwood catfish found in South America, ranging from Colombia and Venezuela to Uruguay and northern Argentina. It is a piscivorous species that preys on catfishes from the families Loricariidae and Doradidae. The name Ageneiosus marmoratus has been merged with A. inermis.

name: Gulper catfish
description: Asterophysus batrachus, also known as the gulper catfish or ogre catfish, is a unique species native to the Rio Negro and Orinoco basins in Brazil, Colombia, and Venezuela. It is the only recognized species in its genus. This catfish species grows up to 28.5 cm in total length, with a dark-colored body and a whitish belly. The gulper catfish is a strict carnivore that swallows its prey whole,

name: Midnight catfish
description: The Leguia (Auchenipterichthys coracoideus) is a small driftwood catfish native to Peru, specifically the upper Amazon River basin. It reaches a length of 10 cm and is popular in the aquarium trade as the zamora woodcat or midnight catfish. Known for its preference for hiding in small spaces during the day, it is a sturdy species suitable for community tanks but may prey on smaller fish.

name: Oil catfish
description: Centromochlus perugiae, also known as honeycomb catfish or oil catfish, is a small benthopelagic fish belonging to the Auchenipteridae family. They have a striking skin pattern and grow to under 3 inches in length. These fish are found in Peru, Ecuador, and Brazil, preferring water temperatures of 26–28 °C and a pH of 6-7. Honeycomb catfish like to hide in driftwood crevices

name: Jaguar catfish
description: The jaguar catfish (Liosomadorsa oncinus) is a driftwood catfish species native to Brazil, specifically in the Branco River and Trombetas River. It is popular in the aquarium trade.

name: Pygmy driftwood catfish
description: Trachelyichthys exilis is a small driftwood catfish species native to Peru, specifically in the Nanay River basin. It reaches a maximum length of 8.0 cm.

Trachelyopterus fisheri, also known as Fisher's woodcat or driftwood catfish, is a slender demersal freshwater fish native to the Sucio River in Colombia. It is the most slender species in its genus and is distinguished by its terminal mouth. While not popular in the tropical aquarium trade, it is listed as "least concern" on the IUCN Red List.

name: Black phantom tetra
remarks: The black phantom tetra enjoy being in groups of 6 or more and a slightly shaded tank. Males may claim small territories and occasionally minor battles may occur. The Phantom tetra goes well with other tetras of similar size. They also prefer floating plants.[27]
description: The Black Phantom Tetra (Hyphessobrycon megalopterus) is a small freshwater fish native to Brazil and Bolivia. It has a tetragonal shape with light grey coloring and a distinctive black patch surrounded by iridescent silver edging. Males have black fins, while females have red pelvic, anal, and adipose fins. They can reach a maximum length of 3.6 cm. In breeding condition, females become plumper and display more intense colors. These

name: Black neon tetra
description: The black neon tetra (Hyphessobrycon herbertaxelrodi) is a freshwater fish native to southern Brazil, commonly found in the aquarium trade. It has an elongated tetra appearance with plain coloration and two distinct white and black longitudinal stripes. This species grows to a maximum length of 4 cm and resembles the neon tetra. They feed on small invertebrates and plants and are best kept in groups of at least 6 in soft acidic water with a

name: Black tetra, skirt tetra
remarks: A highly spirited fish that may occasionally chase its own species as well as harass slow moving fish with long fins. This fish is very hardy and can stand a variety of water qualities. Disease is not a big problem with the black tetra. The black tetra is also known as the black skirt tetra. The female black tetra is more robust and larger than the male.[29]
description: The black tetra, also known as the black skirt tetra, is a freshwater fish native to South America, specifically the Paraguay River basin. It is a popular aquarium fish, growing up to 7.5 cm in length with a greyish coloration and two black vertical bars near its gills. This species is distinguishable by a dense field of dark pigmentation on its body. Black tetras are shoaling fish that feed on small crustaceans, insects, and worms.

name: Bleeding heart tetra
remarks: The bleeding heart tetra is distinguished by the small red spot on both sides of the fish. This fish is very prone to diseases, and can grow larger than most tetra species.[30]
description: The bleeding heart tetra is a freshwater tropical fish native to the Upper Amazon River basin. It grows up to 2.5 inches in size and has a lifespan of around five years. Males have longer extended dorsal and anal fins, while females are more full-bodied. Both sexes have a distinctive blood-red spot in the pectoral area and a black and white patch on the dorsal fin. They prefer soft, acidic water between 23-28°C and a diet of prepared and small live

name: Bloodfin tetra
description: The Bloodfin Tetra (Aphyocharax anisitsi) is a characin species originating from the Paraná River basin in South America. It grows up to 5.5 cm in length and is recognized by its blood-red tail, dorsal, anal, and adipose fins against a silver body. Hardy and sociable, they are ideal for novice fish keepers and are best kept in schools of five or more. They thrive in community tanks with other tetras and tropical

name: Blue tetra
description: Knodus borki, also known as the blue tetra, is a small characin species native to Peru, specifically near Iquitos. It inhabits freshwater environments such as rivers, streams, and tributaries, typically at a benthopelagic depth. This tropical fish species grows to about 2 inches (5 cm) in length and is named in honor of German aquarist Dieter Bork.

name: Bucktooth tetra
description: The bucktooth tetra, also known as Exodon paradoxus, is a freshwater fish native to the Amazon Basin and Guyana. It is the only member of the genus Exodon and belongs to the characin family. This fish has a typical tetra appearance with a light tan color, two black spots, and a bright red dorsal fin. Despite its name, it does not have actual teeth. The bucktooth tetra can grow up to 12 cm in length and feeds on

name: Buenos Aires tetra
description: The Buenos Aires tetra, also known as Hyphessobrycon anisitsi, is a popular tropical fish native to South America, specifically found in the La Plata region of Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay, and southeastern Brazil. They are freshwater fish known for their flashy red coloration, silver metallic body, and black marking on the dorsal fin. These tetras are social fish that swim in schools and are relatively large for tetras, growing up to 7.5 cm

name: Cardinal tetra
remarks: Similar to the Neon Tetra, but slightly larger and doesn't prefer to school as much. They need much larger tanks, although their temperament is similar.[31]
description: The cardinal tetra (Paracheirodon axelrodi) is a small freshwater fish native to the upper Orinoco and Negro Rivers in South America. It is known for its vibrant red and iridescent blue coloration, resembling a cardinal's robes. This popular aquarium fish is closely related to the neon tetra but can be distinguished by its more intense red color and vibrant blue stripe. Cardinal tetras are predominantly predatory, feeding on small aquatic animals in slow-moving, shallow waters.

name: Cave tetra, blind tetra
remarks: The cave tetra is the blind cave form of the Mexican tetra. This tetra prefers low to moderate lighting.[32]
description: The Mexican tetra, also known as the blind cave fish, is a freshwater fish native to Texas and Mexico. It can grow up to 12 cm in length and is peaceful in nature. The blind cave form of this fish has no eyes or pigment, with a pinkish-white color. It prefers water with a pH of 6.5-8, hardness up to 30 dGH, and a temperature range of 20-25°C. In the wild, it feeds on crust

name: Diamond tetra
description: The diamond tetra (Moenkhausia pittieri) is a small freshwater fish found in Lake Valencia, Venezuela. It displays sexual dimorphism with males having longer dorsal fins and brighter colors. They are popular in aquariums due to their attractive appearance. These fish prefer slow-moving streams with vegetation and are threatened by habitat destruction. Diamond tetras are omnivores, feeding on small animal items in the wild and accepting various foods in captivity. They can spawn in aquariums with proper conditions

name: Ember tetra
remarks: Ember tetras have been known to live ten years or more. May become stressed by the presence of larger fish.[33]
description: The Ember Tetra (Hyphessobrycon amandae) is a small freshwater fish native to Brazil, specifically the Araguaia River basin. They have a maximum length of around 2 cm and are known for their striking orange and reddish coloration. Ember Tetras are commonly kept in aquariums by hobbyists and require a minimum tank size of 10 gallons with live plants. They thrive in acidic water with a pH near 6.6 and a temperature range of

name: Emperor tetra
description: Nematobrycon palmeri, also known as the emperor tetra, is a characid fish native to Colombia. It has a purple hue that stands out in subdued lighting with floating plants. Males have metallic blue eyes, a three-pronged tail, and longer anal fins compared to females. They are omnivores and can be fed a variety of foods including live and frozen options. Breeding can occur in well-planted tanks, and babies can be raised on live and

name: Flame tetra
description: The flame tetra, also known as the red tetra or Rio tetra, is a small freshwater fish native to Southeast Brazil. It reaches about 2.5 cm in length and has a striking appearance with a flame red body and red fins. The species is endangered in the wild due to habitat loss, pollution, and introduced species. However, it is commonly bred in captivity and popular in the aquarium trade, with various selectively-bred forms available. The flame tetra is a peaceful schooling

name: Garnet tetra, pretty tetra
description: Hemigrammus pulcher, also known as the pretty tetra or garnet tetra, is a popular aquarium species originating from the Peruvian Amazon. It has a pale-lemon body with a black area on the flanks and grows up to 4 cm. Males can be distinguished from females by the shape of their swim bladder. They thrive in soft, acidic water with temperatures between 23-27°C. Peaceful and social, they should be kept in groups of 6

name: Glass bloodfin tetra
description: The Glass Bloodfin Tetra, Prionobrama filigera, is a Characid fish native to the Amazon River basin. In the wild, it feeds on aquatic insect larvae and crustaceans. In an aquarium, they can be fed commercial dry fish foods, live, and frozen foods like daphnia and bloodworms. They thrive in groups of at least 8 fish in a well-planted tank of 15 gallons. They breed in harder and more alkaline water than

name: Glowlight tetra
description: The glowlight tetra, Hemigrammus erythrozonus, is a small tropical fish from the Essequibo River, Guyana, South America. It has a silver body with a bright iridescent orange to red stripe extending from the snout to the tail base. description: The green neon tetra (Paracheirodon simulans) is a freshwater fish native to South America, specifically the upper Orinoco and Negro Rivers. It is smaller and slimmer than the neon tetra, with more brilliant blue-green coloring. This fish grows to about 3.5 cm in length and is kept in aquariums. It is also known as the blue or false neon. The green neon tetra requires soft, acidic water and temperatures between 24-29°C.

name: Head and tail light tetra

name: January tetra
description: The Costello tetra is a characin species native to the Amazon basin, specifically in Brazil and Peru. It is also known as the January tetra or green neon. This fish species is commonly kept in aquariums and can be fed a diet of flakes, pellets, and live foods.

name: Lemon tetra

This species prefers clear, slightly acidic waters with moderate current flow and is best kept in planted aquariums in groups of at least six individuals. Lemon tetras are hardy and adaptable to a wide range of water conditions, with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.

name: Neon tetra
remarks: Neon tetras must be kept in groups of at least a half-dozen, as they are a shoaling species. With peaceful dispositions, they are also able to be kept with other species of non-aggressive fish.[36]

name: Red Eye tetra

name: Red phantom tetra

name: Rosy tetra

name: Royal tetra

name: Splash tetra

name: Jellybean tetra

name: Long-fin tetra

name: Niger tetra

name: Yellow-tailed Congo tetra

name: Common hatchetfish

description: The common hatchetfish, also known as the river hatchetfish (Gasteropelecus sternicla), is a tropical freshwater fish native to South America, particularly the Peruvian and middle Amazon regions, the Guianas, and Venezuela. name: Marbled hatchetfish

description: The marbled hatchetfish (Carnegiella strigata) is a small freshwater fish native to South America, typically reaching 3.5 cm in length. It has a distinct hatchet shape with a gold line from its eye to caudal fin and a brown and cream marble-like pattern below. This species prefers soft, acidic water and is an omnivore. Marbled hatchetfish are shy and should be kept in peaceful communities or species tanks in small schools.

name: Black-winged hatchetfish

name: Pygmy hatchetfish

They are peaceful and suitable for community tanks. Named after George S. Myers, a prominent ichthyologist known for his work on South American fishes.

name: Golden pencilfish
description: Nannostomus beckfordi, also known as the golden pencil fish or Beckford's pencil fish, is a small freshwater fish from the characin family Lebiasinidae. It is commonly found in swamps and slow-moving waters in Brazil, Guyana, French Guiana, and Suriname.

name: Hockeystick pencilfish
description: Nannostomus eques, also known as the diptail pencilfish, is a small freshwater fish from South America. It was first described in 1876 and is characterized by its elongated body and horizontal stripes. It is commonly found in Brazil, Peru, Colombia, and Guyana, and is popular in the aquarium trade due to its unique swimming behavior.

name: Barred pencilfish

This species is unique in that it features five broad, comma-like patches on its body instead of the typical horizontal stripes seen in its genus. The fish is named after tropical fish importer/exporter Heinrich Espe.

name: Dwarf pencilfish

It belongs to the Nannostomus genus and is characterized by its elongated body and horizontal stripes. It is one of the smallest members of its genus, reaching a maximum size of 35mm. This species is popular in the aquarium trade and has been recorded in countries such as Brazil, Guyana, Colombia, Suriname, and Peru.

name: Coral-red pencilfish

It boasts a striking coral red coloration with black stripes, with mature males having a thickened anal fin. name: Three-lined pencilfish

name: Red piranha

name: Hujeta gar

It can reach up to 30 cm in length and is a carnivorous predator that feeds mainly on small fish. name: Spotted headstander

name: Sunshine peacock cichlid

name: Pale usisya aulonocara

name: Red fin hap

name: Eureka red peacock
description: Aulonocara jacobfreibergi, also known as the Eureka Red Peacock or Freiberg's Peacock, is a species of fish in the Cichlidae family. It is a colorful fish with red or yellow color morphs and can grow up to 15 cm in length. Endemic to Malawi, it is found in various locations in Lake Malawi. name: Spilo

name: Blue dolphin cichlid, lumphead cichlid

name: Afra cichlid, dogtooth cichild

It is a peaceful cichlid that reaches up to 15 cm in length and prefers water with a pH of 7.8-8.9 and a temperature range of 23-26 °C. name: Electric blue cichlid

name: Malawi eyebiter

It can grow up to 23 centimeters in length, with males being larger than females. They have a narrow, laterally compressed body with a large mouth and long jaws. name: Yellow Top Mbamba

name: Chipokee cichlid
description: Aulonocara chipokae, also known as Melanochromis chipokae, is a cichlid species endemic to Lake Malawi, specifically found at Chipoka. It prefers habitats with sand patches among rocks. description: Parachromis dovii, also known as the wolf cichlid or rainbow bass, is a large and predatory cichlid species native to Central America, specifically found in Honduras, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica. It can grow up to 14 kg in weight and 80 cm in length, making it one of the largest cichlids. This species primarily feeds on other fish and is important for local fisheries and game fishing. While sometimes kept in aquariums, they require special care

name: Texas cichlid, Rio Grande cichlid
description: The Texas cichlid, also known as the Rio Grande cichlid, is a freshwater fish native to the United States, specifically found in the lower Rio Grande drainage in Texas and northeastern Mexico. It can grow over 13 inches and is recognized by its cream and turquoise spots. This cichlid prefers water temperatures between 68-82°F and exhibits complex reproductive behavior with long parental care. It has an omnivorous diet and can be an aggressive invasive species in certain environments. The fish

name: Green terror
description: The green terror (Andinoacara rivulatus) is a colorful freshwater cichlid originating from South America. Males can grow up to 30 cm, while females reach around 12 cm. They are known for their aggressive behavior, but peaceful individuals exist. Juveniles are tan with silver-blue flecks, while adults display iridescent blue, green, and orange colors. They prefer a pH of 6.5-8.0, water hardness of 25.

name: Blue acara
description: The blue acara (Andinoacara pulcher) is a colorful freshwater fish from Venezuela and Trinidad, belonging to the cichlid family. They can reach lengths of up to 16 cm and have a stocky body with a steel blue-gray coloration, horizontal green lines on their faces, and blueish-green scales. They prefer tropical climates and water with a pH of 6.5-8.0, hardness of 25° dGH, and a temperature of 22

name: Thread-finned acara
description: The threadfin acara (Acarichthys heckelii) is a South American cichlid fish found in the Amazon and Essequibo basins. It is the only species in the genus Acarichthys and is known for its elongated dorsal fin rays. This fish has a brownish-silver upper body, silvery flanks, and a pale belly with distinct markings. It is a benthic feeder, sifting through sand or mud for invertebrates

name: Eartheater cichlid
description: Geophagus altifrons is a freshwater eartheater cichlid native to the Amazon River Basin, Brazil, and also found in Singapore. It grows up to 22.5 cm in length and is known for sifting through sand for food. This species prefers clear and blackwater environments and is commonly found in the pet trade, often mislabeled as Geophagus surinamensis.

name: Demon eartheater
description: Satanoperca jurupari, also known as the demon eartheater, is a cichlid species found in the Amazon basin in South America. It can grow up to 18.5 centimeters in length and is known for its feeding strategy of sifting through substrate for food. While primarily an invertivore, it can also be an omnivore in disturbed environments. This species is popular in the aquarium trade and exhibits parental care, with parents incubating eggs in their bu

name: Greenstreaked Eartheater, cupid cichlid
description: Geophagus cupido, also known as the green-streaked eartheater or cupid cichlid, is a species of cichlid found in the Amazon and Essequibo basins across Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Guayana, and Peru. It can reach a maximum length of 11.7 cm (4.6 in) and a weight of 55.32 g (1.95 oz). This fish is occasionally found in the aquarium trade.

name: Keyhole cichlid
description: The keyhole cichlid (Cleithracara maronii) is a popular cichlid fish species native to tropical South America, specifically found in the lower Orinoco Basin in Venezuela and river basins in The Guianas. It is known for its tan-colored ovate body with a distinctive black spot on its upper flank, which gives it the common name "keyhole cichlid." This species is peaceful, shy, and should not be housed with aggressive fish.

name: Flag cichlid
description: Mesonauta festivus, also known as the flag cichlid, is a cichlid species found in various river basins in Brazil, Peru, Paraguay, and Bolivia. It can grow up to 12.1 cm (4.8 in) in length and is popular in aquariums. Initially thought to be the only species in its genus, taxonomic reviews in 1991 and 1998 identified a total of six recognized species. While aquarium specimens are often labeled

name: Angelfish
remarks: In an enclosed tank habitat, the fish's territorial, aggressive nature is heightened, so don't house angelfish with shy species that are intimidated by pushy, boisterous fish.[45]
description: Pterophyllum scalare, also known as angelfish, is a common freshwater species native to the Amazon Basin in Peru, Colombia, and Brazil. They are found in swamps with dense vegetation and clear or silty water. Their natural habitat ranges from a pH of 6.0 to 7.0, with water temperatures between 26 to 30°C. Angelfish have a varied diet including fish fry, shrimps, worms, and insects. In captivity

name: Altum angelfish
description: Pterophyllum altum, also known as the altum angelfish, is a large fish species found in the Orinoco River Basin and Upper Rio Negro watershed in South America. It can grow up to 38 cm in height and has a silver base color with brownish/red vertical stripes and red striations in the fins. The species is difficult to breed in captivity and prefers soft, well-oxygenated waters with a pH range of 4.5 to 5.

name: Spotted angelfish
description: Pterophyllum leopoldi, also known as the teardrop angelfish, is a small angelfish species native to the Amazon River, Essequibo River, and Rupununi River. It is distinguished by the absence of a pre-dorsal notch and a black blotch at the dorsal insertion on the 4th vertical bar. It is often confused with P. dumerilii in the aquarium trade. This species reaches a length of 10

name: Common discus, red discus
description: Symphysodon discus, also known as the red discus or Heckel discus, is a cichlid species native to the Amazon Basin in Brazil, specifically in the lower Rio Negro, upper Uatumã, Nhamundá, Trombetas, and Abacaxis rivers. They thrive in blackwater habitats with temperatures ranging from 26–32 °C (79–90 °F) and a low pH of 4.2–5.2. These fish can

name: Blue discus, green discus
description: Symphysodon aequifasciatus, also known as the blue or brown discus, is a cichlid species found in the eastern and central Amazon Basin. It prefers lentic habitats with high temperatures (25–32 °C) and a pH of 5.2–7.7. Typically growing up to 15.2 cm in length, it is popular in aquariums. Taxonomy debates exist, with suggestions to split it into three groups: brown discus,

name: Oscar
remarks: Many people that purchase these fish do not realize that the fish could grow to a foot long (30 cm) within a year. Due to their fast growth rate and large size as an adult, they are often kept in aquariums that are too small for them.[46]
description: The oscar (Astronotus ocellatus) is a popular cichlid fish species native to tropical South America and commonly found in the Amazon River basin. They are known for their vibrant coloration, ability to rapidly change colors, and distinct yellow-ringed spots on their bodies. Oscars are omnivores and feed on a variety of prey including catfish, shrimp, insects, and fruits. In captivity, they require a diet rich in vitamin C to maintain their health. Oscars

name: Chocolate cichlid
description: The emerald cichlid (Hypselecara temporalis) is a small fish native to South America, specifically Brazil, Colombia, and Peru. It belongs to the Cichlidae family and can grow up to 12 inches long. It thrives in tropical climates with temperatures ranging from 25 to 30 degrees Celsius.

name: Severum
description: Heros efasciatus is a tropical freshwater cichlid native to the Amazon basin in South America. It is commonly seen in the aquarium trade, often in its gold color variation. This species is known for being a frugivore, especially during the wet season. Its popularity in the aquarium trade has been increasing, but there are concerns about over-exploitation due to its low densities and low fecundity.

name: Uaru, waroo
remarks: Also known as the Triangle Cichlid.
description: Uaru amphiacanthoides, also known as the uaru or triangle cichlid, is a cichlid species from South America, specifically found in the clear streams of the Amazon Basin. It can grow up to 25 centimeters (9.8 inches) in length. The uaru is valued as a food source by indigenous populations and is popular in the aquarium trade.

name: Zebra Pike Cichlid

name: Butterfly peacock bass
description: The Butterfly Peacock Bass, scientifically known as Acharnes speciosus or Cichla ocellaris, is a large cichlid species native to South America, specifically the Marowijne and Essequibo drainages in the Guianas and the Branco River in Brazil. name: Orinoco peacock bass
description: Cichla orinocensis, also known as the Orinoco peacock bass or tucunaré miri, is a large cichlid native to the Rio Negro and Orinoco River basins in northern South America. It prefers blackwater rivers and can tolerate turbid waters. Adults can reach up to 62 cm in length and are identified by three large gold-edged dark spots on their body. name: Speckled peacock bass
description: Cichla temensis, also known as the speckled pavon or speckled peacock bass, is a large South American cichlid prized for both food and sport fishing. It can reach up to 1m (3.3ft) in length and 13kg (29lb) in weight, making it the largest cichlid in the Americas. name: Canara pearlspot
description: The Canara pearlspot, also known as banded chromide or Canara pearlspot cichlid, is an endangered freshwater cichlid species endemic to South Karnataka, India. It belongs to a small genus of cichlids from Asia and does not occur in brackish waters. This species reaches a length of 11.5 centimeters (4.5 inches) and is sought after in the aquarium hobby, though it is somewhat rare. Breeding in captivity has been reported

name: Green chromide
description: The green chromide (Etroplus suratensis) is a cichlid fish native to India and Sri Lanka, known for its attentive parental care and popularity as a food delicacy. It is also called pearlspot cichlid, banded pearlspot, and striped chromide. In Kerala, it is known as karimeen, in Tamil Nadu as pappan or pappa, in Goa as kalundar, and in Odisha as kundal. It has been

name: Orange chromide
description: The orange chromide, also known as Etroplus maculatus, is a cichlid fish native to freshwater and brackish streams, lagoons, and estuaries in southern India and Sri Lanka. It is popular among fishkeeping hobbyists and commonly kept in aquariums. This species belongs to the Cichlidae family and can grow up to 8 cm in length. Orange chromides coexist with green chromides and prey on their eggs and larvae, while

name: Pinstripe damba
description: Paretroplus menarambo, also known as pinstripe menarambo or pinstripe damba, is a cichlid fish species found in the Sofia River system in northwestern Madagascar. It is threatened by invasive species and over-fishing but is part of captive breeding programs. name: Blood parrot cichlid

They are semi-aggressive and can prey on smaller fish. These cichlids can grow up to 8 inches in length and live for 10 to 15 years. name: Flowerhorn cichlid
remarks: Not considered a separate species of cichlid but a hybrid.[47]

They originated in Malaysia in the late 1990s and have since become popular in the US, Asia, and Europe. They are hybrids with a nuchal hump on their heads and are commonly kept by hobbyists. name: Arulius barb
description: The Arulius barb (Dawkinsia arulius) is a tropical cyprinid fish native to the Kaveri River basin in southeast India. It has various common names like Tamiraparani barb, Silas barb, and longfin barb. name: Bigspot barb, Duncker's barb
description: Barbodes dunckeri, also known as the bigspot barb or clown barb, is a cyprinid fish native to the Malay Peninsula, residing in clear streams and acidic swamps. It is a popular species in the aquarium trade. Discovered by Ernst Ahl in 1929, it was named in honor of German ichthyologist Georg Duncker.

name: Black ruby barb

They have a striking appearance, with mature males displaying a dark ruby-red color and females having black markings on their fins. These fish grow up to 2-3 inches in length and prefer cool, shady streams with gravel or sand substrates. Their diet consists of algae and detritus, and they

name: Cherry barb
description: The cherry barb (Puntius titteya) is a small tropical freshwater fish native to Sri Lanka, with introduced populations in Mexico and Colombia. It is a popular species in the aquarium trade but is threatened by overcollection and habitat loss. This fish has a compressed body, reaching up to 5 cm in length, with females having a fawn coloration and males displaying a deep red color when breeding. name: Clipper barb

name: Clown barb
description: Barbodes everetti, also known as the Clown barb or Everett's barb, is a cyprinid fish found in Borneo and Sumatra. It lives in clear streams in forested foothills and shallow forest floor puddles. The fish feeds on small crustaceans, worms, insects, and plants. It can grow up to 15 centimeters in length and is popular in the aquarium trade.

name: Denison's barb, red line torpedo barb
description: The Denison barb, also known as Denison's barb or roseline shark, is an endangered cyprinid fish native to the Western Ghats in India. It has a torpedo-shaped body with silver scales, a red line running from the snout to the tail, and a black line below it. They typically grow to 9-11 centimeters and are active shoaling fish. The species is endangered due to pet collection, with efforts being made to breed them in captivity

name: Gold barb
description: Barbodes semifasciolatus, also known as the Chinese barb or Gold Barb, is a popular aquarium fish native to the Red River basin in southeast Asia. It has a distinctive appearance with highly arched backs, metallic green or yellow-green sides, and a whitish belly. Adult Gold Barbs can reach up to 7 centimeters in length and primarily feed on invertebrates and plant matter. They are active, mildly aggressive schooling fish that thrive in community tanks. name: Golden barb
description: The golden barb (Pethia gelius) is a small cyprinid fish native to Asia, specifically Pakistan, India, and Bangladesh, and has been introduced to Colombia. It prefers rivers and standing water with a silty bottom in a tropical climate. This fish thrives in water with a pH of 6.0-6.5, hardness of 8-15 dGH, and a temperature range of 68–77 °F (20–25 °C).

name: Greenstripe barb
description: The greenstripe barb (Puntius vittatus) is a tropical freshwater and brackish fish found in Asia, specifically in Pakistan, India, and Sri Lanka. It belongs to the Cyprinidae family and can grow up to 5 centimeters in length. name: Indian Glass Barb
description: The Indian glass barb (Laubuka laubuca) is a cyprinid fish found in various countries including Pakistan, India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Nepal, and Indonesia. It has also been spotted in the Mekong and Chao Phraya rivers.

name: Melon barb
description: The melon barb (Haludaria fasciata) is a cyprinid fish native to rivers in South India's Western Ghats region. It thrives in tropical waters with a pH of 6.0—6.5, water hardness of 5 dGH, and temperatures of 22–26 °C (72–79 °F). This species, reaching 6 centimeters (2.4 inches) in length, is commonly found in the aquarium trade.

name: Odessa barb
description: The Odessa barb (Pethia padamya) is a small cyprinid fish native to Central Myanmar, known for its colorful appearance with males displaying a bright red stripe along their body. They are best kept in groups of 5 or more in a community tank with ample hiding spaces and a secure lid due to their jumping behavior. name: Onespot barb

It was first described in 1822 and can grow up to 4 inches in length. Males are yellowish with orange shades on their anal and ventral fins, turning bright orange during mating, while females are silver with clear fins. name: Pool barb
description: The Pool Barb (Puntius sophore) is a tropical freshwater and brackish fish native to Asia, specifically found in countries like India, Nepal, Bangladesh, and China. description: Puntigrus partipentazona, also known as the Dwarf Tiger Barb, is a small cyprinid fish native to Southeast Asia, specifically found in Thailand, the Malay Peninsula, and Cambodia. name: Rosy barb

name: Shortfin barb
description: Shortfin barb (Enteromius brevipinnis) is a small cyprinid fish found in southern Africa, specifically in the Sabie-Komati and Steelpoort-Limpopo river systems. It prefers well-vegetated headwater streams and can grow up to 4.5 centimeters in length. This species is also popular in the aquarium trade.

name: Snakeskin barb

It can grow up to 8.8 centimeters (3.5 inches) in total length. The name rhomboocellatus comes from the rhomboid ocellus markings on its flanks, which inspired its common name.

name: Swamp barb

It has a silver-green body with black markings, including a distinct black blotch behind the gill opening and on the caudal peduncle. The males have a red dorsal fin with black spots. name: Tiger barb, sumatra barb

description: The tiger barb, also known as the Sumatra barb, is a tropical cyprinid fish native to the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, and Borneo in Indonesia. name: Spanner barb, t-barb

It can grow up to 18 centimeters in length and is popular in the aquarium trade. This species inhabits clear streams in mountain areas, especially near waterfalls, preferring rocky stream beds. name: Fiveband barb, pentazona barb
description: The six-banded tiger barb (Desmopuntius hexazona) is a small Southeast Asian cyprinid fish found in blackwater streams, peat swamps, and freshwater habitats in the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, and Borneo. name: Checker barb

Adult males have red fins with black tips and grow up to 5 cm in length. They prefer tropical waters with pH 6.0-6.5, hardness of 10.0 dGH, and a temperature of 68–75 °F (20–24 °C). Omnivorous, they feed on worms

name: Tinfoil barb
description: The tinfoil barb (Barbonymus schwanenfeldii) is a tropical freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia, particularly the Mekong and Chao Phraya basins. It can grow up to 14 inches in length and has a lifespan of 10 to 15 years. This species prefers water with a pH of 6.5–7.0, hardness up to 10 dGH, and a temperature range of 72–77 °F.

name: Black shark
description: The black sharkminnow, also known as the black shark or black labeo, is a freshwater fish found in various river basins in Southeast Asia. It can grow up to 90 cm in length and weigh up to 7 kg. While sometimes found in the aquarium trade, it is not recommended for home tanks due to its large size and aggressive behavior.

name: Siamese algae eater, fringe barb

It is known for its algae-eating habits and distinctive appearance, with a long body, olive to dark brown dorsal area, and yellowish white lower half. name: Red-tailed black shark

It is popular in aquariums for its black body and vibrant red or orange tail. The species is now only found in one location in the Chao Phraya basin. name: Rainbow shark

It has an elongated body with red to orange-red fins and can grow up to 6 inches long. There are variations such as the albino red-fin shark and the "ghost sharkminnow." name: algae eater

name: Espei rasbora

This species is primarily found in Thailand and Cambodia, with a population also present on Phú Quốc island in Vietnam.

name: Lake Kurumoi rainbowfish
description: The Lake Kurumoi rainbowfish (Melanotaenia parva) is a freshwater rainbowfish species found in West Papua, Indonesia. It is endemic to the small Lake Kurumoi in the Bird's Head Peninsula. The species is primarily threatened by habitat loss and its wild population may have been extirpated from its native range.

name: Neon rainbowfish
description: The dwarf rainbowfish (Melanotaenia praecox) is a colorful species native to the Mamberamo River basin in West Papua, Indonesia. It is popular in the aquarium trade, reaching up to 5-8 cm in length. Males are brighter and have deeper bodies than females, with bright blue, iridescent bodies and colorful fins. They are active and known to jump. This omnivorous species is an egg-scatterer and easy to breed. They are schooling

name: Eastern rainbowfish
description: The Melanotaenia splendida splendida, or eastern rainbowfish, is a subspecies of fish native to Australia. It is commonly found in river systems east of the Great Dividing Range in Queensland, Australia. These fish are known to form large schools and can also be found in lakes and reservoirs. They are popular as tropical aquarium fish, growing up to 14 cm in length. Males display a range of colors, while females and juveniles are silvery with translucent

name: Banded rainbowfish
description: The banded rainbowfish, also known as the Jewel rainbowfish, is a species of rainbowfish found in North Australia and Queensland. They can reach a length of 12-15 cm and have a distinct dark mid-lateral band and bright red/yellow fins. These active shoaling fish breed intermittently throughout the year, with males competing for territory and female attention. They prefer habitats with strong water flow, sandy substrate, and dense vegetation. Banded rainbowfish are opportunistic omnivores

name: Celebes rainbow
description: The Celebes rainbowfish (Marosatherina ladigesi) is a small, slender fish endemic to Sulawesi, Indonesia. Males grow to 6-8 cm, females to 5-7 cm, with transparent bodies and a blue stripe along the sideline. Males have elongated black fins. They prefer streams and estuaries with high oxygen levels, feeding on worms, insects, and plant debris. In captivity, they are peaceful, growing up to 7.

name: Forktail blue-eye
remarks: These fish need a larger aquarium than their size suggests. Though they only grow to a length of about 2 inches, they are happiest in groups of 8 – 10 or more, and they appreciate lots of swimming space.[67]
description: The forktail blue-eye (Pseudomugil furcatus) is a small rainbowfish species found in rainforest streams in Papua New Guinea. Formerly known as Popondetta or Popondichthys, it is now classified under Pseudomugilinae.

name: Spotted blue-eye
description: The spotted blue-eye (Pseudomugil gertrudae) is a small fish native to Papua New Guinea and northern Australia. It can adapt well to captivity and is suitable for small freshwater aquariums. This species has an elongated body, reaching up to 3 cm in length, with a transparent to pale silver-white coloration and distinctive black markings on the rear half of the body. It inhabits rivers, streams, and swamps with a pH range of 3.68

name: Red neon blue-eye
description: The red neon blue-eye (Pseudomugil luminatus) is a fish species found in swamps near Timika in Papua, Indonesia. It belongs to the subfamily Pseudomugilinae.

name: Pacific blue-eye
description: The Pacific blue-eye (Pseudomugil signifer) is a small fish species native to eastern Australia, commonly found in rivers and estuaries from North Queensland to southern New South Wales. It has two subspecies that have been considered separate species in the past. Recognizable by its blue eye-ring and two dorsal fins, it feeds on water-borne and flying insects. This fish adapts well to captivity and can reach up to 3.5 cm in length. It forms loose

name: Delicate blue-eye
description: The delicate blue-eye (Pseudomugil tenellus) is a fish species belonging to the subfamily Pseudomugilinae. It is native to northern Australia and Papua New Guinea.

name: Madagascar rainbowfish
description: Bedotia madagascariensis, also known as zona, is a fish species belonging to the Bedotiidae family. Endemic to Madagascar, it inhabits rivers and lakes in the region between the Ivoloina River and the Manambolo Creek. This species is popular in the aquarium trade, often mistaken for B. geayi. Unfortunately, habitat loss poses a significant threat to its population. Described by Charles Tate Regan in 1903, the type specimen

name: Empire gudgeon
description:
Species Name: Hypseleotris compressa (Empire Gudgeon)

Description:
- Endemic to Australia and south-central New Guinea.
- Described by Gerard Krefft in 1864.
- Elongated body up to 12 cm long, males larger than females.
- No lateral line, ctenoid scales.
- Color varies, yellowish-tan to golden-brown head, whitish-red abdomen.
- Males display bright colors during breeding season to attract mates

name: Purple sleeper gudgeon
description: The northern trout gudgeon (Mogurnda mogurnda) is a freshwater fish found in northern Australia and New Guinea. It belongs to the Eleotridae family.

name: Peacock gudgeon, Peacock goby
remarks: A little territorial with its own kind but is suitable for many communities of small, peaceful fish. Ideal tankmates are other species from Papua New Guinea, such as Popondetta sp. rainbowfishes; but tetras, rasboras, Corydoras cats and virtually any other small peaceful species are also suitable.[68]
description: The peacock gudgeon, also known as the peacock goby, is a tropical freshwater fish endemic to eastern Papua New Guinea. It belongs to the Eleotridae family and is the only member of its genus. These fish reach up to 7.5 cm in length and display blueish and silvery bodies with pink, yellow, and black markings. Males are more colorful and larger than females, with distinct physical differences. They exhibit suction feeding and prey on insects and small

name: Black toraja goby
description: Mugilogobius sarasinorum, also known as Sarasin's goby, is a small fish species endemic to Lake Poso in Sulawesi, Indonesia. It can grow up to 8 centimeters in length and is significant to local commercial fisheries. The species is named after Swiss naturalists Paul Sarasin and Fritz Sarasin.

name: Bumblebee goby
description: The bumblebee goby (Brachygobius doriae) is a small species of goby found in fresh and brackish waters of Southeast Asia. It can grow up to 4.2 centimeters in length and is popular in the aquarium trade. The species is listed as Least Concern with no known threats.

name: Knight goby
description: Stigmatogobius sadanundio, also known as the knight goby, is a gray-blue fish native to South Asia. It can be found in freshwater and occasionally brackish waters in estuaries and rivers. This species has two dorsal fins with dark spots and can reach a length of 9 centimeters. In aquariums, they should be kept singly or with mid-level species as they are territorial. They prefer low light and plenty of rocks and caves. Knight gobies

name: Barred mudskipper
description: The barred mudskipper, also known as the silverlined mudskipper, is a species of mudskipper found in marine, fresh, and brackish waters across the Indian Ocean, western Pacific Ocean, and Australia. It inhabits mangrove forests and nipa palm stands, capable of moving across mud surfaces out of water. This species can grow up to 19 centimeters in length and is sometimes kept in aquariums. It is known to host parasites such as Acantho

name: Atlantic mudskipper
description: The Atlantic mudskipper (Periophthalmus barbarus) is a semi-aquatic fish found in tropical Atlantic coasts of Africa, Indian Ocean, and western Pacific Ocean. It can grow up to 16 cm in length and has unique adaptations for both land and water locomotion. They are carnivorous, reaching sexual maturity at around 10 cm in length. They have a lifespan of about five years and are used by humans for food, bait, and medicinal purposes. The species

name: Bearded worm goby
description: The Bearded worm goby (Taenioides cirratus) is a fish species found in the Indian Ocean and the western Pacific Ocean. It can grow up to 30 cm in length and is commonly found in estuaries and coastal waters with mud substrates. They feed on small crustaceans and invertebrates. This species can survive in fresh, brackish, and salt water, and is known to be invasive in certain lakes, impacting the populations of shrimp and b

name: Marbled goby
description: The marble goby, also known as Oxyeleotris marmorata, is a large gobioid fish found in fresh and brackish waters across Southeast Asia, including the Mekong and Chao Praya basins. It can reach up to 65 cm in length but typically stays around 30 cm. This species is important for local fisheries, aquaculture, and the aquarium trade. It is highly valued for its tasty white flesh and is believed to have healing properties

name: Crazy fish
description: Butis butis, also known as the crazy fish or duckbill sleeper, is a small sleeper goby native to brackish and freshwater coastal habitats of the Indian Ocean and western Pacific Ocean. They are known for their unique behavior of swimming vertically or even upside down while hunting.
