Rhinogobius duospilus is a small goby species native to China and Vietnam, typically found in fresh or brackish waters. They can grow up to 4.5 centimeters in length and primarily feed on larvae and similar creatures in the wild, but can also be fed brine shrimp or blood worms in captivity.

name: Striped sleeper goby
description: The fat sleeper (Dormitator maculatus) is a small fish from the Eleotridae family, known for its flat head and two distinct dorsal fins. They are fully scaled with higher fins on their body, and have a dark brown body with reddish dorsal and anal fins. They have a dark blue spot around their gill covers. Found in fresh and brackish waters from the Bahamas to Brazil, they prefer intertidal areas on muddy bottoms.

name: West African lungfish
description: The West African lungfish, also known as the Tana lungfish, is a freshwater fish found in West and Middle Africa, as well as the northern half of Southern Africa. It has a long eel-like body with prominent snout and small eyes, growing up to 1 meter long and weighing up to 4 kilograms. This species is an obligate air breather and can aestivate for up to a year during dry seasons. It primarily feeds on mollusks, crabs,

name: Spotted lungfish
description: The spotted lungfish, also known as the slender lungfish (Protopterus dolloi), is a freshwater fish found in Middle Africa, specifically in the Congo, Kouilou-Niari, and Ogowe river basins. It is one of four species in the Protopterus genus. This fish primarily resides in the middle and lower Congo River basin, with a demersal behavior, living in riverbeds and Stanley Pool. During spawning season, females can be seen in open water

name: South American lungfish
description: The South American lungfish (Lepidosiren paradoxa) is a unique fish species found in swamps and slow-moving waters of the Amazon, Paraguay, and lower Paraná River basins in South America. It is an obligate air-breather and the sole member of its family Lepidosirenidae. The fish has an elongated body, reaching up to 125 cm in length, with thin pectoral fins and larger pelvic fins set far back. Adults are

name: Australian lungfish
description: The Australian lungfish, also known as the Queensland lungfish, is the only surviving member of the family Neoceratodontidae and one of six extant lungfish species globally. Endemic to Australia, this ancient fish species has remained virtually unchanged for over 100 million years, earning it the title of a living fossil. It is found in slow-flowing rivers and still waters in southeastern Queensland, preferring temperatures between 15-25°C. The lungfish can grow up to

name: Ocellate river stingray
remarks: has venomous barbs that contain a protein based poison, if you happen to accidentally get stung you should submerge the wound in as hot as water as you can as this breaks down the protein[69]
description: The ocellate river stingray, also known as Potamotrygon motoro or the peacock-eye stingray, is a freshwater stingray found in South America. It is the most widespread species in its family, ranging across various river basins. It can grow up to 50 cm in disc width, 1 m in total length, and 35 kg in weight. The stingray has a circular disc shape, raised eyes, and typically beige or brown coloration with yellow

name: Black devil stingray
remarks: see above
description: The Xingu River ray, also known as the white-blotched river stingray, is a freshwater fish endemic to the Xingu River basin in Brazil. It prefers clear waters with rocky bottoms and can reach up to 40 cm in disc width, 75 cm in total length, and 20 kg in weight. Females are larger than males. It is closely related to P. henlei and P. albimaculata. The Xingu River ray is a venomous sting

name: Gray bichir, Senegal bichir, or dinosaur bichir
size: 70.0 cm (27.6 in) maximum length[70]40.0 centimetres (15.7 in) in captivity[71]
remarks: Peaceful but preys on anything smaller than its mouth[72]
description: Polypterus senegalus, also known as the Senegal bichir or gray bichir, is a fish species popular in the pet trade due to its primitive and prehistoric appearance. It is native to Africa and is commonly kept in captivity by hobbyists. This elongated fish has a lungfish-like appearance, with subtle patterns and occasional darker blotches on its scales. It has poor eyesight and relies on its sense of smell to hunt prey. The fish has a pair of

name: Ornate bichir
remarks: Peaceful but preys on anything smaller than its mouth[72]
description: The ornate bichir, Polypterus ornatipinnis, is a bony fish native to Lake Tanganyika and the Congo River basin in Central and East Africa. It features black and yellow patterning on its body, head, and fins, with 9 to 11 dorsal spines. This species is the largest of the "upper jaw bichirs," reaching up to 60 cm in length. Ornate bichirs can vary in color from dark brown to

name: Retropinnis bichir
remarks: Peaceful but preys on anything smaller than its mouth[72]
description: The West African bichir, also known as the retropinnis bichir, is a freshwater fish found in the central Congo River basin and Ogooué River in Africa. It has a long, slender body that can grow up to 34 cm in length. This primitive fish has tetrapod-like jaw structure, rudimentary lungs, and can breathe air when needed. It has an olive-brown dorsal surface with darker markings, creamy-white irises with black speckles

name: Barred bichir
remarks: Peaceful but preys on anything smaller than its mouth[72]
description: The barred bichir, also known as Polypterus delhezi, is a unique fish species found in the Congo River. It is commonly available in pet stores and has a greyish color with hints of yellow or green. This fish has a primitive body structure with a distinct dorsal fin made of spines and a modified swim bladder that functions as a lung. Its scales are covered with 'ganoin', similar to tooth enamel, and are non-overlapping rhombus-shaped scales. The

name: Saddled bichir
remarks: Peaceful but preys on anything smaller than its mouth[72]
description: Polypterus endlicheri, also known as the saddled bichir, is a large freshwater fish from the Polypterus genus. It can reach up to 63 cm in length and 3.3 kg in weight. Identified by its flattened head, prominent lower jaw, and green and yellow coloration with black spots. This piscivorous species feeds on fish, snails, and crustaceans. They reproduce during the rainy season and are known as egg scatterers. Found

name: Reedfish
size: 31.4 cm (12.4 in) at maturity, 37 centimetres (15 in) maximum length[76]
description: The reedfish, also known as the ropefish or snakefish, is a unique fish species native to West and Central Africa. It belongs to the Polypteridae family and is the only member of the Erpetoichthys genus. This fish has the ability to breathe atmospheric air due to a pair of lungs, allowing it to survive in oxygen-poor waters. Reedfish are threatened by habitat loss mainly due to palm oil plantations, agriculture, deforestation, and urban development

name: Sterlet
description: The sterlet (Acipenser ruthenus) is a small sturgeon species native to Eurasian rivers flowing into the Black Sea, Azov Sea, and Caspian Sea. Due to overfishing, pollution, and habitat destruction, it is considered vulnerable by the IUCN. Sterlets feed on benthic organisms and can live up to 25 years, with females reaching sexual maturity at 4-12 years. They spawn from April to June, with females laying 15

name: Shovelnose Sturgeon
description: The shovelnose sturgeon (Scaphirhynchus platorynchus) is the smallest freshwater sturgeon in North America, also known as hackleback, sand sturgeon, or switchtail. They are abundant in the Missouri River and Mississippi River systems, reaching up to 1 meter in length and 4.8 kilograms in weight. They have a shovel-shaped snout, four barbels on their rostrum, and scale-like plates on their belly.

name: American paddlefish
description: The American paddlefish, also known as the Mississippi paddlefish, is the last living species of paddlefish and is closely related to sturgeons. It has a unique paddle-shaped rostrum used for filter feeding on zooplankton. The species is highly derived and has specialized adaptations for feeding. American paddlefish populations have declined due to overfishing, habitat destruction, and pollution. They are protected under state, federal, and international laws. The fish are long-lived, reaching lengths of

name: Bowfin
description: The bowfin (Amia calva) is a bony fish native to North America, known by various names like mudfish and dogfish. It is considered a "primitive fish" due to its ancient lineage and retained ancestral characteristics. Bowfins are freshwater predators found in the eastern United States and southern Canada, with a preference for vegetated habitats. They have a unique ability to breathe both water and air, enabling survival in low-oxygen conditions. Bowfins are long-lived, reaching

name: Spotted Gar
description: The spotted gar is a freshwater fish native to North America, characterized by dark spots on its head, fins, and body. It has an elongated mouth with needle-like teeth and grows to about 2-3 ft in length and weighs 4-6 lb. Gars have diamond-shaped, enamel scales and are found in clear, slow-moving waters. They are voracious predators, feeding on fish, shrimp, insect larvae, and algae. Spotted gar spawn in shallow waters with vegetation,

name: Longnose Gar
description: The longnose gar, also known as longnose garpike or billy gar, is a ray-finned fish in the family Lepisosteidae. They have a torpedo-shaped body with olive brown to green coloration, elongated jaws, and sharp teeth. Longnose gars can be found in freshwater lakes, brackish water, swamps, and rivers in North and Central America. They are known for their ability to breathe both air and water. Longn

name: Florida Gar
description: The Florida gar (Lepisosteus platyrhincus) is a mid-sized gar species found in the US, particularly in Georgia and throughout peninsular Florida. They can grow over 3 ft in length and weigh between 1.36 to 4.36 kg. These fish have a distinctive appearance with black spots on their head and body, olive-brown coloring on the back, and a white to yellow belly. They inhabit lowland streams, canals, and lakes

name: Alligator Gar
description: The alligator gar (Atractosteus spatula) is a large freshwater fish native to North America, closely related to bowfins. They are known for their resemblance to alligators, with broad snouts and long, sharp teeth. Alligator gars can grow up to 10 ft in length and weigh over 100 lb. They have a torpedo-shaped body with ganoid scales that provide excellent protection. These fish are ambush predators, primarily feeding on fish but also consuming waterfowl

name: Cuban Gar
description: The Cuban gar, also known as manjuarí, is a tropical freshwater fish found in rivers and lakes of western Cuba and the Isla de la Juventud. It can also inhabit brackish water. This species spawns seasonally in floodplains and typically grows to around 1-2 meters in length. Cuban gars are solitary hunters but may form larger groups during spawning season. They are top-level predators, feeding on freshwater fishes and birds. The species is known for its

name: Tropical Gar
description: The tropical gar, also known as Atractosteus tropicus, is a fish species native to Central America, specifically found in both Pacific and Atlantic drainages from southern Mexico to Costa Rica. In Central America, it is referred to as gaspar, and in Mexico, it is known as pejelagarto. This gar species thrives in various freshwater and brackish water environments like rivers, lakes, and floodplains, avoiding strong currents. It can grow up to 1

name: Blunt-jawed elephantnose
description:
Species: Gnathonemus tamandua
Common Name: Blunt-jawed elephantnose
Scientific Name: Campylomormyrus tamandua
Description: Brown or black fish with a long elephant-like snout and mouth near the tip.
Habitat: Rivers in West and Middle Africa.
Diet: Worms, fish, and insects.

name: Peters' elephant nose
description: Peters's elephant-nose fish (Gnathonemus petersii) is an African freshwater fish known for its trunk-like protrusion on the head. It uses electrolocation to find prey and has the largest brain-to-body oxygen use ratio of all vertebrates. This species is native to West and Central Africa, preferring muddy, slow-moving rivers with cover. It grows to around 23-25 cm in length and has a dark brown to black coloration with a forked tail fin

name: African butterflyfish
description: The freshwater butterflyfish, Pantodon buchholzi, is a small fish species with large pectoral fins, belonging to the family Pantodontidae in the order Osteoglossiformes. It is not related to saltwater butterflyfish. This carnivorous fish feeds on aquatic insects and smaller fishes, primarily hunting at the water's surface. They have specialized adaptations for surface hunting, including upturned mouths and the ability to jump and glide above the water. Freshwater butterflyfish spawn

name: Aba aba
description: Gymnarchus niloticus, also known as aba or African knifefish, is an electric fish found in swamps, lakes, and rivers in various basins in Africa. It has a long, slender body without caudal, pelvic, or anal fins, relying on an elongated dorsal fin for propulsion. This nocturnal species uses a weak electric field for navigation and hunting, showcasing electroreception abilities. Females lay eggs in floating nests, and adults guard the

name: Reticulated knifefish
description: The reticulated knifefish (Papyrocranus afer) is a freshwater fish native to tropical West Africa, specifically found in the Niger basin and other coastal river basins. It can reach a maximum length of 80 cm and a weight of 1.3 kg. This fish has a laterally flattened body with small scales, a feather-like dorsal fin, and an elongated anal fin with no spines. It can breathe air at the water's surface using its

name: African brown knifefish
description: The African brown knifefish (Xenomystus nigri) is a unique fish found in various river basins in Africa. It has a ventrolaterally flattened and elongated body resembling a knife blade, with fused caudal and anal fins for precise control in water. This nocturnal species has excellent night vision and uses barbels for hunting. It lays 150-200 small eggs and feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and snails. It

name: Royal knifefish
description: The royal knifefish, also known as the Indochina featherback or Chitala blanci, is a ray-finned fish found in the Mekong basin in Cambodia, Laos, Thailand, and Vietnam. It is sometimes sold in the aquarium trade under the name royal clown knifefish.

name: Clown knifefish
description: The clown featherback, also known as the clown knifefish, is a nocturnal tropical fish with a long, knife-like body. It is native to freshwater habitats in Southeast Asia but has been introduced to other regions. This species is invasive and popular in aquaculture and the aquarium trade. It can reach up to 1m in length and has a distinct appearance with black spots ringed with white. Clown knifefish are carnivorous and prefer live prey, but can adapt

name: Asian arowana
remarks: Preys on anything smaller than its mouth.[77]
description: The Asian arowana, also known as the Asian bonytongue or dragonfish, is a freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia. It has special cultural significance in areas influenced by Chinese culture due to its resemblance to the Chinese dragon. The fish comes in various color varieties, with distinct features such as metallic scales and double barbels. Asian arowanas are considered symbols of good luck and prosperity and are highly valued in the aquarium trade, with some varieties being more endangered than others.

name: Gulf saratoga
description: Scleropages jardinii, also known as the Gulf saratoga or Australian bonytongue, is a freshwater fish native to Australia and New Guinea. It has a dark-colored body with pearly spots, large pectoral fins, and can grow up to 90 cm in length and weigh up to 27 kg. This species is not endangered and inhabits still clear waters in northern Australia and central-southern New Guinea. Gulf saratoga are carnivorous,

name: Southern saratoga
description: The southern saratoga, also known as the spotted bonytongue, is a freshwater bony fish native to Australia. It belongs to the arowana family and is a carnivorous mouthbrooder. This species can grow up to 90 centimeters in length and 4 kilograms in weight. They have a dark brown to olive green coloration with red or orange dots on their large, bony scales. Southern saratoga are found in turbid waters and prefer still waters

name: Silver arowana
remarks: Preys on anything smaller than its mouth.[77]
description: The silver arowana is a South American freshwater fish known for its large scales, long body, and tapered tail. It can grow up to 1.2 meters in length and is found in the Amazon, Essequibo, and Oyapock basins. This predatory fish is popular in aquariums but requires a large tank due to its size and predatory nature. It is known for its ability to jump out of the water to catch prey and is sometimes called 'water monkey.' The

name: Black arowana
remarks: Preys on anything smaller than its mouth.[77]
description: The black arowana, a South American freshwater bony fish, is a predatory species that requires a large tank if kept in aquariums. It is commonly found in the Rio Negro basin and has an elongated body with a tapered tail, reaching up to 1.2 meters in length. Juveniles are black with yellow markings that disappear as they grow, developing a dark iridescent steel grey to blue coloration. They are known for their unique appearance and are sometimes called water monkey

name: Pirarucu
description: Arapaima gigas, also known as pirarucu, is a large freshwater fish native to the Amazon River basin. It is one of the largest freshwater fish species, reaching lengths up to 450 cm and weights up to 200 kg. This species is an obligate air breather, surfacing regularly to gulp air. Arapaima gigas has a streamlined body with flexible, armor-like scales for protection. It primarily feeds on fish but also consumes insects, fruits,

name: African arowana
description: The African arowana (Heterotis niloticus) is a bonytongue fish species closely related to arapaimas. It has a long body, large scales, and a terminal mouth, feeding primarily on plankton. This species can reach up to 1m in length and weigh up to 10.2kg, with a color range of gray, brown, or bronze. African arowanas have air-breathing organs, enabling them to survive in low

name: Freshwater moray
description: Gymnothorax polyuranodon, also known as the freshwater moray, is a species of moray eel native to the Indo-Pacific region. It can reach up to 1.5 meters in length, with a yellow or light tan body covered in dark brown spots. This carnivorous eel primarily feeds on fish and has small teeth and slightly toxic saliva. It is found in shallow coastal waters, estuaries, and river mouths, with evidence suggesting it is a cat

name: Hingemouth
description: The hingemouth (Phractolaemus ansorgii) is a small freshwater fish unique to west central Africa. It belongs to the subfamily Phractolaeminae of the family Kneriidae. This fish has a distinctive mouth that can extend like a small trunk and contains only two teeth in the lower jaw. Its swim bladder has two compartments and can function as a lung, enabling the hingemouth to survive in low-oxygen environments.

name: Black ghost knifefish
remarks: Not to be confused with the featherback "knifefish" of the Bonytongue group (see above)
description: The black ghost knifefish, a tropical freshwater fish native to South America, is popular in aquariums due to its unique appearance and behavior. It grows up to 18-20 inches in length and requires a large tank of at least 100 gallons. These nocturnal fish are weakly electric, using electric signals to locate prey. name: Brown ghost knifefish
description: The brown ghost knifefish (Apteronotus leptorhynchus) is a weakly electric knifefish known for its negligible brain aging. They belong to the family Apteronotidae and are hardy fish that feed on tiny fish, crustaceans, and insect larvae in the wild. In aquariums, they readily accept frozen foods. This species exhibits indeterminate growth and lacks reproductive senescence.

name: Glass knifefish
description: Eigenmannia virescens is a weakly electric freshwater fish native to South America. It is popular in the aquarium trade and is recognized by black lines on its body, particularly on the anal fin. This species, like others in its order, can generate electric fields through an electric organ in its tail. name: Electric eel
description: Gymnotus electricus, also known as Electrophorus electricus, is a South American electric fish species. It is not an eel but a knifefish, with a cylindrical body that can grow up to 2 meters in length and 20 kg in weight. This species has electrogenic tissue that allows it to produce electric discharges. It has three pairs of abdominal organs that generate low and high voltage electric discharges for hunting and defense. Electric eels can control their

name: Northern pike
description: The northern pike (Esox lucius) is a carnivorous fish found in fresh and moderately salty waters of the Northern Hemisphere. They are known for their large size, with average lengths of 40-55 cm and maximum recorded lengths of up to 150 cm. Pike are olive green with light and dark markings, and they are ambush predators that feed on fish, frogs, insects, and even small mammals and birds. Pike are solitary predators that migrate during spawning season and are popular among

name: Indian glassy fish
description: Indian glassy fish, also known as Parambassis ranga, is a freshwater species native to South Asia. It has a transparent body, with males developing a dark edge on the dorsal fin, and can grow up to 80mm in length. These fish are prolific breeders during the rainy season and feed on crustaceans and invertebrates. While not a food source for humans, they are popular in the aquarium trade. They thrive in slightly soft to moderately hard water and a temperature

name: Amazon leaffish
description: The Amazon leaffish (Monocirrhus mimophyllus) is a small fish found in the Amazon basin in South America. It closely resembles a dead leaf with its flattened body and filament at the tip of the lower jaw. This species is highly predatory, feeding on small invertebrates and fish, with larger individuals mainly preying on fish. name: African leaffish
description: The African leaffish (Polycentropsis abbreviata) is a small freshwater fish native to western Africa, growing up to 8 centimeters in length. It is commonly found in the aquarium trade and is the sole member of its genus. The classification of this species is debated, with some authorities placing it in the family Nandidae and others in Polycentridae.

name: Nile perch
description: The Nile perch (Lates niloticus) is a large freshwater fish native to various river basins in Africa. It is a significant economic and food source in East Africa, reaching lengths of nearly 2 meters and weighing up to 200 kg. Nile perch are fierce predators, feeding on fish, crustaceans, molluscs, and insects. They have been introduced to various lakes in Africa, with negative impacts on native species and ecosystems. name: Indonesian tigerfish
description: Datnioides microlepis, also known as the Indonesian tiger perch, is a freshwater fish endemic to the Malay Peninsula and Indonesia. It has a deep body with 6-7 dark vertical bars on a yellowish-grey background. This species can reach up to 55 cm in length and is a predatory fish, feeding on crustaceans, smaller fish, annelids, and insects. They prefer large lowland rivers with submerged branches and flooded forests. Datnioides microle

name: Silver tigerfish
description: Datnioides polota, also known as the silver tigerfish or silver tiger perch, is a ray-finned fish found in southern Asia and New Guinea. It belongs to the family Lobotidae. This species has a maximum length of 30 cm and is known for its variable coloration with dark vertical bars on the body. name: Banded archerfish
description: The banded archerfish (Toxotes jaculatrix) is a silvery brackish water fish with semi-triangular markings along its sides. It is known for spitting jets of water to "shoot down" prey up to 3 meters away. Found in Indo-Pacific waters, it inhabits river mouths and mangrove estuaries. This species can reach up to 30 cm in length and has distinct black bars on its body. Banded archerfish are omn

name: Seven-spot archerfish
description: Toxotes chatareus, also known as the common archerfish, is a perciform fish found in southeast Asia, the Indo-Pacific, and Australia. They typically grow up to 20 centimeters but can reach 40 centimeters in length. These fish are omnivorous, feeding on insects, fish, and vegetation at the water's surface. name: Spotted scat
description: The Scatophagus argus, also known as the spotted scat or butterfish, is a fish species found in the Indo-Pacific region, including areas like Japan, New Guinea, and southeastern Australia. They inhabit coastal muddy areas, estuaries, and mangroves. This fish has two color morphs, green and ruby/red, with a rectangular body shape and distinctive brown to red-brown spots. name: African scat

It has an oval shape with a compact head and small mouth, reaching up to 30 cm in length. This species has a cream color with brown bars and sometimes an orange or red patch on the forehead. name: Silver moony
description: Monodactylus argenteus, also known as the silver moonyfish, is a species native to the western Pacific and Indian Oceans, including the Persian Gulf and Red Sea. name: African moony
description: Monodactylus sebae, also known as the African moony, is a fish species found in fresh, brackish, and marine waters along the eastern Atlantic coast, from the Canary Islands to Angola. name: Freshwater pipefish
description: Doryichthys martensii, also known as the longsnouted pipefish, is a freshwater fish belonging to the Syngnathidae family. It is native to Indonesia, Malaysia, Brunei Darussalam, and Thailand, inhabiting rivers and streams. This species feeds on mosquito larvae and can grow up to 15 centimeters in length. name: African freshwater pipefish
description: Enneacampus ansorgii, also known as the African freshwater pipefish, is a member of the Syngnathidae family. It is found in coastal rivers and streams across Western Africa, from the Gambia River to the Cuanza River in Angola. The specific name likely honors the explorer William John Ansorge.

name: Fire eel
description: The fire eel (Mastacembelus erythrotaenia) is a large spiny eel native to Southeast Asia and commonly found in the aquarium trade. It is not a true eel but an elongated fish with a pointed snout and underslung mouth. This species has a dark brown/grey body with bright red lateral stripes and spots that intensify with age. It can grow up to 1 meter in length and is typically found in slow-moving rivers and flood plains

name: Tire track eel
description: The zig-zag eel, also known as Mastacembelus armatus, is a freshwater fish native to the Indian Subcontinent, Southeast Asia, and other regions. It is popular in aquariums due to its unique appearance and behaviors. This eel-like fish can reach up to 20" in captivity and has a snake-like body with distinctive markings. description: The peacock eel, also known as Macrognathus siamensis or spotfin spiny eel, is a freshwater fish species found in Southeast Asia, particularly in the Mekong and Chao Phraya basins across countries like Thailand, Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam. name: Lesser spiny eel
description: The lesser spiny eel, Macrognathus aculeatus, is a Southeast Asian freshwater fish from the Mastacembelidae family. They have a yellow upper body with a black line, and a lower body that is a mix of white and brown. The eel has small spines along its backbone and prominent eyespots on its dorsal fin. name: Freshwater needlefish
description: Xenentodon cancila, also known as the freshwater garfish, is a needlefish species found in South and Southeast Asia. It is a popular aquarium fish with various common names like needlefish, silver needlefish, and freshwater gar. They have an elongated body with beak-like jaws and silvery-green coloration with a dark band along the flank. name: Green spotted puffer

name: Dwarf pufferfish

They are popular in aquariums for their vibrant colors and small size, reaching a maximum length of 3.5 cm. These pufferfish are found in heavily vegetated waterways, where they feed on small animals. They breed throughout the year, with spawning pairs producing 1-5 eggs. name: Fahaka puffer
description: The Fahaka pufferfish, also known as the Nile puffer or globe fish, is a tropical freshwater species found in various basins in Africa. They can grow up to 43 cm in length and have the ability to inflate when threatened. These pufferfish carry the toxin tetrodotoxin and mainly feed on benthic organisms such as freshwater mussels and snails. They are commonly found in large rivers, open water, weed beds, and vegetated fringes.

name: Amazon puffer
description: Colomesus asellus, also known as the Amazon puffer, is a popular freshwater pufferfish species native to the Amazon, Essequibo, and Orinoco basins in South America. It is recognized for its green and white coloration with black transverse bands and a distinctive black band around the base of the caudal fin. name: Everglades pygmy sunfish
description: Elassoma evergladei, also known as the Everglades pygmy sunfish, is a small fish species endemic to North America. It can grow up to 3.4 cm in length and has a brown body with dark spots and red spots on its fins. Males are black with iridescent blue spots, while females are brown with mottled coloring. They are found in freshwater habitats from North Carolina to Alabama and from southern Florida to the Everglades.

name: Blackbanded sunfish

It belongs to the sunfish family and is relatively small, reaching a maximum length of 10 cm and an average lifespan of 3-4 years. name: Freshwater blenny
description: The freshwater blenny (Salariopsis fluviatilis) is a small fish species belonging to the Blenniidae family. It is primarily found in African rivers and brooks in Algeria and Morocco that flow into the Mediterranean Sea. In Europe, it can be found in various freshwater bodies in countries such as Albania, Croatia, France, Greece, Italy, Montenegro, Spain, and Portugal. name: Brook stickleback
description: The brook stickleback (Culaea inconstans) is a small freshwater fish found in the US and Canada. It grows up to 2 inches long and inhabits clear, cool streams and lakes. It feeds on small invertebrates, algae, and insect larvae. Spawning occurs in midsummer, with males building nests and providing protection for the eggs. name: Banded darter
description: Etheostoma zonale, also known as the banded darter, is a freshwater fish endemic to the eastern United States, mainly found in the Mississippi Basin. It inhabits small to medium-sized rivers with riffles over cobble or gravel, feeding on small insect larvae. The species is known for its colorful males during spawning season in spring. name: Gilt darter
description: The gilt darter (Percina evides) is a freshwater ray-finned fish belonging to the darter family Percidae. Males are more colorful than females, reaching about 9 cm in length. They primarily feed on small aquatic insect larvae and form territories during the breeding season. The species is sensitive to siltation and pollution, leading to extirpation from some river systems. name: Orangethroat darter
description: The orangethroat darter (Etheostoma spectabile) is a freshwater fish found in the central and eastern United States, particularly in the Mississippi River Basin and Lake Erie Basin. It inhabits shallow gravel riffles in streams and rocky runs in headwaters, feeding on aquatic larvae and small invertebrates. Spawning occurs in spring in sandy and gravelly bottoms of riffles. name: Rainbow darter

It grows to 2-3 inches in length and is sensitive to pollution. Easily identified by dark spots on its back and vibrant colors on its fins, the rainbow darter feeds on small invertebrates. name: Splendid darter
description: The splendid darter (Etheostoma barrenense) is a freshwater fish endemic to the Barren River system in Kentucky and Tennessee. It inhabits rocky pools in creeks and rivers, with specialized reproductive behaviors. The species faces threats from changes in land use, dams, and habitat destruction.
